data.title: Postal Realty Trust: Unique REIT Scaling A Fragmented Market With Predictable Returns
data.description:
Introduction

The last time I covered Postal Realty Trust (PSTL), I highlighted their unique position as the largest REIT focused on USPS-leased properties, with plenty of room to grow in a very fragmented market, with a nearly perfect occupancy rate and a strong, sustainable dividend yield.

Despite the stock returning ~25% since then (compared to a nearly flat S&P 500), I believe PSTL continues to trade at an attractive level, with significant potential to grow in a very fragmented market, especially once macro conditions improve.

Internal Developments

PSTL reported a solid Q4 and 2025 overall, beating the market’s FFO and revenue estimates and delivering a solid AFFO of $42.11 million in 2025 ($1.32 per share), which is significantly above the $33.72 million seen in 2024 ($1.16 per share), for a roughly 13.8% increase per share, while the company continued its acquisitions with another 65 properties added in Q4, bringing 2025’s total to 216 properties and already 26 more in Q1 2026 (as of February 13).

Meanwhile, their guidance expects an AFFO between $1.39 and $1.41 per share, with this very small spread proving the resilience and reliability of the business, expecting between $115 million and $125 million in acquisitions throughout the year. At midpoint, that’s an increase of roughly 6% in AFFO per share, which continues to be solid, similar to their 5.8% CAGR since 2020 despite the near-term weakness.

Financially, based on PSTL’s latest report, we can see a solid position overall, with the assets covering their debt obligations very well despite the limited cash position, and we should keep in mind that these assets are not only depreciated (for tax purposes) but also recorded at the price of acquisition, which can be significantly lower than the current ones, which explains why the market cap tends to be well above the equity.

As mentioned before, PSTL’s debt maturity schedule remains very well spread throughout the future, with no maturity until 2028, allowing them to wait for better financing costs if they want to while the environment potentially improves, which is certainly a great option to have nowadays. I believe we’re looking at a young company that’s still developing its debt schedule, so the growth is far from over, although the net debt to annualized adjusted EBITDA stands at ~5.2x, which is common for a REIT.

Following their 1% increase in the quarterly dividend, PSTL pays a yield of roughly 5.05% nowadays, meaning roughly $32.53 million per year (without accounting for an increase in 2026), for a very solid payout ratio of ~77.25% based on last year’s AFFO, leaving a lot of room for even better increases.

Macro Developments

Since the last article was published, we’ve had a very volatile environment on several fronts, with the market clearly paying attention to everything that’s happening given PSTL’s performance, from the longest US Government shutdown in history to rate cuts and fears surrounding the US economy.

Something I always want to highlight for REITs like PSTL is the importance of external capital, as these companies have to pay most of what they make back to us by design, relying on external capital to develop, which can be tough to do when the cap rates they get fluctuate around 7.5% to 8% (not uncommon for REITs).

Until not long ago, issuing stock came at a more than 6% cost for this company for several years (pretty much since the rate hikes started), while their debt carries floating interest rates tied to SOFR (which they fix through rate swaps), roughly 1.5 or 2 percentage points above the SOFR, usually, which limits the gap between their investments and their cost significantly.

Sure, things are improving; the SOFR is falling, their cost of issuing equity (the dividend) is also lower following the jump in price, and that can theoretically allow them to expand at a greater pace given the very fragmented industry they’re playing in, as mentioned before.

However, although we’re talking about some near-term improvements, the environment remains very uncertain, and it’s not impossible to see the market demand higher yields from the US going forward given the potential for renewed tariff fears despite the Supreme Court’s decision, rising debt, or even Japan’s plans that add an extra layer of pressure and uncertainty to the mix, which the market has to take into account when deciding these rates, looking at much more than just what the Fed does.

Again, the situation in Japan, for example, may seem like “old news” that’s getting overshadowed by headlines like the recent economic growth data (2.2%, the weakest growth rate since 2016 excluding the pandemic - although still beating expectations), but it’s important to understand that this issue is not over, and it’s very important because Japan remains the number one foreign owner of US treasuries.

Following the country’s changed approach (recently hiking rates while others are cutting, after holding them very low), we can see its bond yields rising, which can lead to a selloff of US treasuries while money would chase the better yields (especially if US yields continue dropping) potentially leading to sudden jump in bond supply, which can weaken the prices and push the yield up, leading to higher-for-longer yields and potential for a weaker dollar regardless of what the Fed does, especially if the market’s opinions and expectations about the country don’t improve.

Japan’s debt issuance is expected to grow by 28% in fiscal 2029 from 2026, which adds another layer of fear and uncertainty alongside their shifted approach, potentially leading to higher borrowing costs that can attract money into the country and sustain the selloff, which is why I believe this issue is still far from over despite the market’s focus shifting.

As for the near future, we can see a significant amount of PSTL’s leases expiring, which can allow them to continue their switch to leases that include contractual rent escalators instead of flat rents, which can support their solid AFFO growth rates going forward alongside the mark-to-market rents, current escalators, and acquisitions.

Still, PSTL remains in a solid leadership position and should be able to keep expanding as they consolidate the industry, being the largest single owner of USPS properties while holding about 8% of the leased market.

On the other hand, although it’s a public service with a duty to serve 100% of Americans - not a business - the USPS is far from a great position (which I detailed in the first coverage), with their current ten-year plan potentially leading to consolidation actions that could imply closing locations and optimizing their network, which can be a risk for PSTL given the upcoming lease expirations, and things ultimately remain uncertain in this environment.

As a note, PSTL's focus on mission-critical real estate is a big advantage here, as the company generally has a nearly 100% renewal rate and still holds a nearly perfect ~99.8% occupancy rate, and it's important to remember that even though the company itself is relatively young, it's still funded by industry veterans.

Risks Reiterated

Although the company plays in a very fragmented market and should be able to keep expanding and introduce rent escalators in their new contracts, there is certainly the possibility of seeing worse financing costs going forward given the environment, and “growth at all costs” is not a good approach, in my opinion.

Meanwhile, the US treasuries would also reflect better yields as a result, potentially forcing the market to adapt the price to a more appropriate risk-reward level in case things get worse.

Valuation

For PSTL’s DCF to Equity valuation, based on their latest number of shares outstanding and the midpoint of their 2026 guidance, I’ll assume an AFFO of $47.74 million in 2026, followed by a CAGR of 6% until 2030 (taking into account the effects of their dilution on the per-share amounts) given their solid potential to develop in this fragmented market and assuming better economic conditions, followed by a 4% CAGR for the subsequent 5 years, a 2.5% terminal growth rate, with a 9% discount rate given the overall strong leadership position and significant potential to expand, but also balancing the risks related to the USPS and their exposure to it, with 34.10 million shares outstanding as of December 31, 2025.

This way, we get to an equity value of $866.21 million, for an intrinsic value of $25.4, which is still above the current $19.40 at the moment of writing this, while a better discount rate in case the economic conditions improve and they see more attention from the market could easily place this at $30 or above.

Conclusions

I reiterate PSTL’s Buy rating, as the valuation continues to offer a good margin of safety given the company’s potential, with a solid yield on top that has plenty of room to improve alongside the business.

As a final note, I suggest you check out Easterly Government Properties (DEA) as well, which offers a ~7.7% yield today and leases to the US Government through multi-decade contracts, covered recently in an update here.

data.title: Gold Price Stalls Near $5,200 As U.S.-Iran Talks In Geneva Anchor Geopolitics

By Ezequiel Gomes

Gold (XAUUSD:CUR) traded in a narrow band this Thursday, February 26, holding just under the $5,200 mark as investors watched negotiations between Washington and Tehran in Geneva and weighed whether the market still has enough momentum to push higher.

Price action near the highs

Spot gold was little changed in Thursday trading, hovering near $5,181 an ounce. That kept the metal close to the upper end of its recent range and showed that buyers are still active after this week’s rebound.

April COMEX gold traded near $5,198, lower than the session’s earlier tone, which points to a market that is consolidating rather than accelerating.

Why Geneva matters for gold

The immediate focus is the third round of indirect U.S.-Iran nuclear talks in Geneva. Investors are watching closely because the outcome could reshape the risk premium built into several markets, including precious metals and oil.

That creates a two-sided setup for gold. Ongoing uncertainty around the talks supports haven demand, but signs of progress can also reduce some of the urgency to own defensive assets. In other words, the negotiations are helping keep gold elevated while also making traders cautious about chasing the metal too aggressively at current levels.

The same pattern has shown up across other markets. Oil prices eased on Thursday as optimism around the talks reduced some supply risk concerns - a reminder that any clear diplomatic progress can quickly alter cross-market positioning. That matters for gold because it shows investors are actively repricing geopolitical risk rather than simply adding to it.

Rates and dollar keep the rally measured

The U.S. rate backdrop is still important. The 10-year Treasury yield was holding around 4.03% to 4.05%, a level that is high enough to limit enthusiasm for a non-yielding asset such as gold but not so high that it forces heavy selling.

The dollar was also steady rather than disruptive. The dollar index remained near 97.7 to 97.8, which kept some pressure on bullion by making it more expensive for non-U.S. buyers, but the currency move was not strong enough to knock gold out of its current range.

What traders are watching next

The next obvious macro event is the U.S. Personal Income and Outlays report for January 2026, scheduled for March 13. Because that release includes the PCE price index, it is likely to shape expectations for Fed policy and, by extension, the next move in yields, the dollar and gold.

Until then, the market appears to be balancing three forces at once: strong underlying demand for bullion, resistance near $5,200, and uncertainty around the Geneva talks. That mix can keep gold firm, but it can also make price action look choppy from one session to the next.

In the near term, the metal still looks well supported, but the next push higher may require either a softer rates backdrop or a fresh rise in demand for safe assets. Without that, gold may continue to hover near current levels while traders wait for the next decisive headline.

Meanwhile, an increased interest in gold is being observed against the global stagflation shock and instability, as the gold price has a negative correlation with traditional markets.

data.title: Japan's Inflation Cools Despite Improving Growth, Leaving BoJ In No Rush To Tighten
data.description:
By Min Joo Kang, Senior Economist, South Korea and Japan

Core inflation continued to cool, falling below the BoJ’s target

Japan’s core inflation, excluding fresh food, eased to 1.8% year-on-year in February (vs 2.0% in January, 1.7% market consensus). Government energy subsidy measures drove inflation lower quite meaningfully. Utility prices, such as electricity and gas, fell further by 6.6% in February compared to -2.2% in January. Cereal prices (mostly rice) grew notably less, from 11.3% in January to 7.5%. The high base for rice prices will continue to weigh on inflation throughout this year. Energy subsidies will end soon, so we expect temporary volatility in monthly changes. Yet, other government welfare programs, such as free tuition, are likely to lower inflation in the latter part of the year.

Although core inflation eased, we believe underlying price pressure remained sticky, as most of the price decline was driven by goods rather than services. In a monthly seasonally-adjusted comparison, inflation fell 0.1% month-on-month, with goods prices down 0.6% and services up 0.2%.

Energy and food prices dropped while underlying inflation remain sticky

The BoJ will need additional evidence to hike rates

Going forward, inflation is expected to stay below 2%. Yet, service prices, primarily driven by rising labour costs and strong demand, are likely to remain firm. This is expected to support the Bank of Japan’s policy normalisation of modest rate hikes. We believe it’s important to monitor April inflation data since that’s when many businesses set new prices based on their costs -- at the beginning of the fiscal year. As we mentioned in an earlier publication, the recent BoJ board nominees who lean towards dovish policies will require stricter criteria to be met for rate hikes. Therefore, the BoJ is expected to act in June, once the results of the spring wage negotiations and the April CPI figures have been confirmed.

The dove-hawk balance may not change meaningfully with two new dovish-tilting nominees

Auto sector recovery helped drive monthly data improvement

Industrial production and retail sales rebounded in January, suggesting GDP growth will accelerate in the first quarter. IP rebounded 2.2% MoM in January (vs -0.1% in December, 5.5% market consensus), and retail sales also were up 4.1% (vs -2.0% in December, 1.5% market consensus). Details of both data were quite encouraging, as gains were widely spread. But also, the improvement in auto sector activity was quite impressive. Motor vehicle output rose for the second month, by 9.1% in January, following a 1.4% gain in December. Shipments rebounded to 8.8% after dropping in the previous two months. Motor vehicle retail sales surged 12.5%.

Stronger-than-expected retail sales data indicate that private consumption will lead growth, supported by strong wage growth. We believe lower inflation, helped by subsidies, will partly enhance consumers' purchasing power. Also, the recent rally in the local equity market should contribute positively to consumption. Today’s data support our view that GDP is expected to accelerate in 1Q26, driven by solid exports and consumption.

As we navigate a choppy stock market, investors remain concerned about a shaky macroeconomy and tepid consumer spending data, which applies to all but seemingly one category: sales of used items. Perhaps as a response to high prices and inflation, consumers are increasingly turning to secondhand goods, including and especially in the luxury category, to fulfill their shopping.

TheRealReal (REAL), one of the leading "re-commerce" platforms, clearly demonstrates that shift in spending priorities. The company has showcased accelerating GMV across several quarters, allowing the company to generate meaningful economies of scale. In a market that has been incredibly punishing for growth stocks, TheRealReal has achieved nearly 2x share price appreciation over the past year, and a recent strong Q4 earnings print helped boost shares by a further ~10% (though the stock still remains down in January, along with most other small/mid-cap growth names).

I last wrote a "Buy" article on TheRealReal in November, when the stock was trading at $11 per share. The company has been a major bright spot in my small/mid-cap portfolio, and with strong results and rising GMV under its belt, I don't see TheRealReal's outperformance coming to a halt anytime soon. I'm reiterating my "Buy" rating on this stock.

In my view, there are a number of tailwinds that the company enjoys that cement the bull case for TheRealReal:

  • Accelerating GMV at scale. It's abundantly evident from TheRealReal's results that used luxury commerce is having its moment in the spotlight, with several sequential quarters of GMV growth despite reaching a sizable >$2 billion annual scale.
  • Large TAM. The company believes its annual addressable market for luxury resale in the United States is $200 billion, indicating its current GMV is only about ~1% penetrated into the total opportunity.
  • Consignment focus has improved gross margin profile. In the past, TheRealReal used to run a mix of consignment/third-party sales alongside taking on its own inventory. The company has since shifted to becoming a capital-light, consignment-first business, which has pushed gross margins up to the mid-70%s: allowing for incredible economies of scale.
  • Potential tailwinds from the gold boom. Management notes that one of the most popular categories on TheRealReal's platform is luxury gold watches (think brands like Patek Philippe and Audemars Piguet).
  • Leveraging AI to drive down cost. Though TheRealReal is still trading at rich adjusted EBITDA multiples, its bottom line is growing rapidly thanks to the company's use of automation to keep its cost base at reasonable levels while revenue and GMV expand, allowing for substantial margin expansion.

Stay long here and keep riding TheRealReal's post-earnings momentum higher.

Q4 download

Let's now run through TheRealReal's latest quarterly results in greater detail. The Q4 earnings summary is shown below:

TheRealReal's revenue grew 18% y/y to $194.1 million, beating Wall Street's expectations of $190.8 million (+16% y/y) by a two-point margin. Revenue growth accelerated slightly versus 17% y/y growth in Q3.

The acceleration was driven by a boost in GMV, up 22% y/y to $616 million (and also accelerating two points versus 20% y/y growth in Q3). The company notes that GMV growth was driven by both an increase in the number of sales on the platform as well as a higher average price per sale. We do note that take rates, which represent TheRealReal's revenue as a percentage of consignment GMV sales, dipped -120 bps to 36.5%. This isn't a major concern, however, as the company attributed the take rate erosion due to the higher mix of high-end luxury sales that typically carry lower commissions for TheRealReal (but nevertheless profit strong gross profit dollars).

Meanwhile, the company's active buyer base increased by 32k net-new users in Q4. It's important to note that TheRealReal's core focus for 2026 is to sustain longer-term relationships with its users. It's moving from becoming a transactional platform to an "advisor for the closest." The company is noticing that many of its buyers are eventually also becoming sellers on the platform, and buyers who purchase secondhand luxury often do so with resale value in mind.

The company is realizing this vision through the release of MyCloset, which helps users to track the items they own and get price data for them. Per CEO Rati Levesque's remarks on the Q4 earnings call:
